Poor benefits to comparable companies. Non-native Koreans are treated poorly.

Pros: Hybrid working, ok work laptop, nice office with plenty of parking
Cons: First off this company is not Samsung, but a subsidiary. Anyways, there are a lack of boundaries especially if you are of Korean descent. Management has a need to flex and harass you over every little mistake no matter how small, which naturally leads to a slow burn of resentment. Ineffective ways of doing things are taught and a culture of blaming and shaming is always around the corner. It's hard to get anything done, since a manager or department head is ready to call or jump in on messenger to lecture you about the "proper" ways of doing things here (even if you have followed the rules and you are trying to fix the problem and help those in the company who have generally been ignored).

Review Title: Good Benefit, no life other than work life.
Pros: Health benefit, location, free coffee, discounted snack bar.
Cons:
No personal work life balance. Not an enterprise or big tech company (run like mom and pop). No advancement in career, nor on your knowledge.
If you are starting your career, you need a big company name on your resume, it will be alright, things you learn from the company won't be useful anywhere else. If you are a seasoned engineer, stay away, unless you just want a job with decent pay and if you don't have a personal life, it might work out for you too. Good old boys' system, they have a tendency of overworking Korean speaking employees, if you are not, you will be fine, just do your job and don't speak up, you will have a job. They validate my firm belief in competency breed incompetence, and this company is prime example of it. You will end up doing someone else's job and you won't even be recognized for it.

Good Luck

Pros: Great Structure, Great Pay, Organized

Pros: I've been working for SDS America for almost two years and this has been by far one of the most invaluable experiences for junior level individuals really looking to advance their career and gain some marketable experience. This is a global conglomerate so opportunities are definitely there whether you are in IT or Business. You have exposure to many projects and challenges and take full autonomy over those projects (read: long hours, high reward... if you're intrinsically motivated). The health benefits are great. Culture is all depending on which location you work out of. Training programs are easily accessible and widely encouraged.
Cons: This organization is not for the faint of heart. SDS is still struggling with the clash of "Samsung-style" Korean culture & American workforce culture. If you have zero empathy for other cultures and cannot adapt, you will not survive. No real emphasis on work/life balance. Don't expect to be outrageously compensated either. But like I said, the learning experience is great for those wanting to gain valuable professional experience.

Review Title: If you have any other option, don’t take this job.
Pros: Cafeteria food was cheap and good, free snack in the afternoon once a week.
Cons:
This is the worst company I have ever worked in my 12 years professional career. 
	No family-working balance.   Long hours 9-6, other companies are 9-5.  However, you can never leave at 6pm.  Your manager expects you to stay late every day.  Sometimes work till midnight, and no compensation day/hour.  
	Not flexible.  Too controlling manager style.  No chatting, no talking on the phone during office hour.   Office is so quite, you just need to work like a slave.  You cannot go lunch on your own schedule.  
	No trust between managers and employees.  My co-worker was asked to bring in a doctor’s note for one sick day.  Managers get nerves when people ask for sick days, because they don’t want people to go for interviews. 
	No chance of moving up in the corporate. Korean team drives the project; I did not get to design and contributing my ideas.   
	There are so many people quit during the time I was there.   Turn over rate is very high.

Pros: Only reason to get a job at Samsung SDS America is for their health insurance benefit.
Cons:
1. Don't be fooled by the name Samsung. This company is a subsidiary and still acts like a Start-up company.
2. If you are Asian your salary will be substantially low as opposed to white folks. If there's a government audit the company would be in big trouble.
3. Just terrible management. It's very rare to find a competent manager in the company. The majority of the managers has NO leadership quality. This is by far the biggest problem with the company. Very unfortunate.

Review Title: Glassdoor wouldn't let me give less than 1 star
Pros:
Great benefits
Worked with great people
Cons:
-Staff is very underpaid
-Seems like the company has been hanging on by a thread for years
-For an IT company all the internal systems we use are very outdated
-The Korean culture clashes with the American culture
-Meetings are almost always in Korean even if you do not speak it
-Americans feel like outcasts
-The work day ends at 6pm but if you leave at 6pm you will get dirty looks for leaving on time
-Most of management talks down to its employees and treats them like 2nd rate
-The management style is micro-management
-The company is retroactive to issues it faces instead of proactive
-There are constant rumors of sexual harassment between Korean dispatchers and staff level employees and the company doesn't seem to do anything more than slap them on the hand

Review Title: Worst Company I Have Ever Worked At
Pros: Not much other than health benefits
Cons:
After working here, then eventually experiencing what it's like to work at a good company, it's like night and day.  Every single day would feel physically sick about working here.  I would walk to the front door then imagine if that door had the word, "HELL" printed on it.  People come and go like the wind here.  A lot of the Directors are absolute control freaks who probably have not taken a leadership class in their lives.

Everything here is based on fear, not enthusiasm.  Bosses will use fear against you by only complaining/putting you down/only talking about every thing bad, without saying one good word about you.  Say something wrong during a meeting that might "embarrass" your boss, then they will make you "relive" their experience ten fold.

Pros:
Good benefits, health insurance and dental, and PTO available.
There is ample opportunity to learn, though mostly through trial by fire.
Cons: Bonus is dismal.  "Cheaping out" is a common theme.  Especially when it comes to storage for the systems that are maintained.  Projects and systems show obvious signs of minimal testing, lack of QA, and strict enforcement of tight deadlines to save money.  Resources are stretched to the extreme.

Review Title: They Abuse you and use you
Pros: Good benefits, learn a lot in one year, sr. Hr manager is wonderful and a huge help.
Cons:
Instead of asking the employee what else they would like to be involved in, they go ahead and just force them into certain roles and tasks without any conversation. 
The Korean culture does not work in America. Need to change that mentality. 
There is no team work. It is like the Americans and Koreans are fighting against one another. The Koreans don't want to hear the ideas of the Americans which makes no sense since it would help the business tremendously. 
Their systems are pointless and not helpful. Need to upgrade their outlook system so scheduling can be easier to manage. 
SDS is very outdated compared to other companies.

Review Title: Only good to have the Samsung name on the resume
Pros:
If you actually get hired,  you can say you actually worked for Samsung and everyone would be impressed.

Benefits are good, they give lunch money, and pay is just okay
Cons:
You will sell your soul for working at Samsung.  SDS is the bottom feeder of all Samsung companies.  If you're Korean and not in management, be prepared to work long hours and prepare tons of reports. 

There's too many layers of management and most are unreasonable.  Everyone will start out as a contractor and you'll be lucky if you get hired within a year.   If you want to move up in your career, be prepared to relocate and work long hours.

Not worth the time.

Pros:
In my group I get to work on very cutting edge technologies. We have some really good engineers here.
Health insurance is great, probably the best you'll find anywhere.
Diverse work areas / projects.  It's a conglomerate, so SDS has access to a range of internal and external clients.
Stable relative to startups, or financial firms.
Can get nice gadgets.
Cons:
There has been a push to be more innovative, and flexible.  Some parts of the firm will really feel like a 'big firm', but other parts will feel start-up like.  The spectrum is wide.
I think the overall experience may depend on which group you work in. e.g. traditional vs. new.
Some offices are kind of drab looking.
401k matching not great. Small percentage of the IRS max.

Review Title: Good Benefits, The Work Has Its Ups and Downs
Pros:
Good medical and 401k match
Nice coworkers(even management), subsidized cafeteria lunch, fun activities (Halloween party, ping pong & other Korean game tournaments, volunteer days)
Christmas gift ($400 Samsung gift card or choose from preselected Samsung products)
It’s a pleasure to work with the IT teams on the second floor.
Cons:
B2B projects are all very unprofitable and mostly a waste of time. They mostly resell low margin Samsung devices.
Too dependent on business from Samsung Electronics and that business continues to decline.
Management has the best intentions but is unable to build the right products with the right features the market needs.

Review Title: SDSRA - bad place for your career
Pros: High quality problems to work on (but not enough quantity). Good work/life balance and good facilities (gym, nice office, nice cafe, etc). Good place to get 2 years of experience, but terrible place to stay longer than that
Cons: Low pay - 6% bonuses and 2% raises each year regardless of how well you do. Also no stock and no promotions except for a couple people who know which butts to kiss and how to kiss them. HR is completely out of touch with reality of keeping good people around in Silicon Valley. More than half the team left in the past year and more will leave soon because getting an offer somewhere else is guarantees to be higher pay

Pros: Worked with some of the smartest and brightest people in the IT services industry.  Also a huge focus on teamwork, and a dedication by everyone to do whatever it takes to get the work done.
Cons: Senior executives really don't have a deep understanding of the specific functional areas and lack the industry knowledge to drive business.  Samsung is an organization that develops and nurtures managers that are generalists and more focused on administration and management.  In order to succeed, it needs to invest more in bringing quality talent from within specific industry sectors, especially at the higher levels of the organization.

Pros: best work environment and working condition. The building was equipped with full amenities like cafeteria, restaurant, shops, and gyms (in a separate building) and colleges were the best.
Cons: Busy times, you needed to work over night for weeks. Not very diversified in terms of employees. Uses its own word system which can by annoying sometimes.

Pros: Prestigious Name / Brand and food.
Cons: Stiff Culture | Low morale | Employee high turn over - 80-90% of the time Contractual Positions. ZERO growth. System is Old School / Primitive for being in the I.T. Industry - Ridiculous

Pros:
The physical amenities of the campus are very nice. Lovely space, good cafeteria (though trending downward), good gym, plenty of nooks to work privately. Opportunities to travel domestically and to Korea. 

Colleagues are friendly. Work-life balance (compared to the other offices in Seoul) is good, but be prepared to drop your life/cancel your vacation/work for 48 hours straight if an executive comes to town at the last minute.  

The Samsung name opens a lot of doors and looks very good on the resume.
Cons:
There are exceptionally limited opportunities to move up or succeed unless you are a native born Korea. It's unclear who has it worse, Korean Americans or non-Koreans in terms of being taken seriously, getting put on good projects, or even just your colleagues in Korea being willing to work with you.  Pay for expensive areas to live like Silicon Valley and Seattle is very low. 

Annual reorganizations completely ruin any long-term planning for team. Extreme focus on P&L can make investment efforts that will pay off in a couple years but require initial work to gain traction are killed before they are given a chance. 

HQ is very opaque and it is hard for regional offices to understand strategy and direction for the year. Additionally, the Seoul Office has the final say in absolutely everything. If a product is developed in Samsung SDS America, HQ will take over the project/source code from the regional office. This leaves the individuals in the regional offices demotivated in their work. All initiatives must have a sponsor in the Korean office as well, even if it is a regional initiative.  But if you're not from the Korean office (ie you have prior personal connections) you can't even find who is the right person to talk to about sponsoring.

Review Title: Cutting edge technology, rapidly growing team
Pros: Cutting edge technology, such as Spark distributed computing framework and Scala programming language. Co-workers are good at their fields. Potential access to interesting data.
Cons: HQ is in Korea, so you may get the occasional email with snippets in Korean that you don't understand (day-to-day work is completely in English). Like with any rapidly growing team, projects change, so you have to be flexible.
